oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Grady Martin interviewed by Jay Oermann Side Two
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Grady Martin being interviewed by Jay Oermann. The recording's date is currently unidentified.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Grady Martin
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side Two - (0:02) -- Interview continues with discussion about how many sessions Grady Martin worked in a day. (1:28) -- Grady Martin discusses the scale of union pay ($41.25). (2:05) -- Grady Martin speaks about temporarily getting into songwriting. Mentions his song "Snap Your Fingers," recorded by Joe Henderson (not the jazz saxophonist). (3:02) -- Grady Martin mentions his publishing company with Floyd Cramer. (3:45) -- Interviewer asks about when Floyd Cramer first came to Nashville. Grady Martin mentions that Floyd Cramer first came to Nashville with Webb Pierce. (5:11) -- Grady Martin speaks about helping Ray Edenton into the music business. (6:15) -- Grady Martin mentions that he's always wanted to work with Frank Sinatra. (7:39) -- Grady Martin confirms that he played on Brenda Lee's sessions with Owen Bradley. Goes on to describe his friendship and fondness of Owen Bradley. (8:10) -- Interviewer asks Grady Martin about overdubbing on Hank Williams' records. (9:15) -- Grady Martin describes recording at Fred Rose's garage with Hank Williams. (9:44) -- Grady Martin mentions recording with Jim Reeves and overdubbing those recordings. (11:08) -- Grady Martin speaks about Buddy Harman's humor. (11:49) -- Interviewer asks about Grady Martin's session work with Marty Robbins. (12:32) -- Grady Martin's speaks about Joe Henderson's passing. (14:04) -- Grady Martin speaks about recording with Sister Rosetta at Castle Studios. (14:20) -- Interviewer asks about Grady Martin's work with Jim Bulleit's company, Bullet Records. Grady Martin mentions recording with Cecil Gant. Owen Bradley was also on the session. (15:05) -- Grady Martin speaks about recording with Bob Beckham. (16:52) -- Grady Martin explains his thinking when backing up an artist in the studio. (17:38) -- Grady Martin mentions that Marty Robbins was a "one take wonder" and could record songs in just a few takes. (18:30) -- Grady Martin speaks about recording with Ernest Tubb. Grady once recorded a song with Ernest Tubb that took two days and two nights to record correctly. (21:45) -- Grady Martin speaks about the importance of Red O'Donnell. (23:56) -- Grady Martin speaks about what he learned from Owen Bradley in the recording business. (26:25) -- Grady Martin speaks about the egos of young guitar players. (26:49) -- Grady Martin describes working with Mort Thomasson at the Quonset Hut. Grady and Mort synced up two tape machines to double tracks. This effect was used on one of Grady Martin's albums "Instrumentally Yours." (28:12) -- Interviewer discusses the creation of the idea of "play it until it's right, not necessarily until the three hours is up." (28:37) -- Grady Martin describes recording three tunes in four hours. (29:07) -- "It's probably one of Music Row's most important traditions. It's that the music still comes first."
